texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recently picked up a Dell Optiplex 7060 and I'm using it as my main workstation now. The Fedora installation was easy, but I noticed a variety of "pop" or clicking sounds when audio played, especially terminal bells.
texts.text: I recently picked up a Dell Optiplex 7060 and I'm using it as my main workstation now. The Fedora installation was easy, but I noticed a variety of "pop" or clicking sounds when audio played, especially terminal bells.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If everything was quiet and I triggered a terminal bell, I would hear a loud pop just before the terminal bell sound. However, if I played music and then triggered a terminal bell, the pop was gone.
texts.text: If everything was quiet and I triggered a terminal bell, I would hear a loud pop just before the terminal bell sound. However, if I played music and then triggered a terminal bell, the pop was gone.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A quick Google search told me that the likely culprit was power saving settings on my Intel HD Audio chipset:
texts.text: A quick Google search told me that the likely culprit was power saving settings on my Intel HD Audio chipset:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ lspci | grep Audio
00:1f.3 Audio device: Intel Corporation Cannon Lake PCH cAVS (rev 10)
texts.text:
$ lspci | grep Audio
00:1f.3 Audio device: Intel Corporation Cannon Lake PCH cAVS (rev 10)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Fixing it
texts.text: Fixing it

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's a handy power saving tunable available at
texts.text: There's a handy power saving tunable available at

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
texts.text: /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: that can be usd to adjust the timeout or disable power savings entirely. In my case, the delay was set to one second.
texts.text: that can be usd to adjust the timeout or disable power savings entirely. In my case, the delay was set to one second.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ cat /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
1
texts.text:
$ cat /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That would be good for a laptop use case, but my workstation is always plugged in. I disabled it by setting it to zero:
texts.text: That would be good for a laptop use case, but my workstation is always plugged in. I disabled it by setting it to zero:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# echo 0 > /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
$ cat /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
0
texts.text:
# echo 0 > /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
$ cat /sys/module/snd_hda_intel/parameters/power_save
0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And the pops are gone! My Klipsch speakers have a built in amplifier and it was likely the abrupt changes in current that was causing the popping noises.
texts.text: And the pops are gone! My Klipsch speakers have a built in amplifier and it was likely the abrupt changes in current that was causing the popping noises.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This setting will last until you reboot. You can make it permanent by adding this text to
texts.text: This setting will last until you reboot. You can make it permanent by adding this text to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/modprobe.d/audio_disable_powersave.conf
texts.text: /etc/modprobe.d/audio_disable_powersave.conf

texts.label: code
texts.orig: options snd_hda_intel power_save=0
texts.text: options snd_hda_intel power_save=0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're a laptop user and you want power savings but fewer pops, you could increase the delay to a more acceptable number. For example, setting it to
texts.text: If you're a laptop user and you want power savings but fewer pops, you could increase the delay to a more acceptable number. For example, setting it to

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: would mean that the card will power down after 60 seconds of silence. Just remember that you'll get a nice pop when the 60 seconds has passed and a new sound is played.
texts.text: would mean that the card will power down after 60 seconds of silence. Just remember that you'll get a nice pop when the 60 seconds has passed and a new sound is played.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Learning more
texts.text: Learning more

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Diving into the kernel code reveals the tunable in
texts.text: Diving into the kernel code reveals the tunable in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /sound/pci/hda/hda_intel.c
texts.text: /sound/pci/hda/hda_intel.c

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: The default comes from a kernel config option:
texts.text: The default comes from a kernel config option:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT
texts.text: CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . Most kernel packages on most distributions provide access to the kernel config file that was used to build the kernel originally. It's often found in
texts.text: . Most kernel packages on most distributions provide access to the kernel config file that was used to build the kernel originally. It's often found in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /boot
texts.text: /boot

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (named the same as the kernel version) or it might be available at
texts.text: (named the same as the kernel version) or it might be available at

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /proc/config.gz
texts.text: /proc/config.gz

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For Fedora, the kernel config is provided in
texts.text: For Fedora, the kernel config is provided in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /boot
texts.text: /boot

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: whenever a new kernel is is installed. I inspected mine and found:
texts.text: whenever a new kernel is is installed. I inspected mine and found:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ grep HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT /boot/config-4.20.13-200.fc29.x86_64
CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT=1
texts.text:
$ grep HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT /boot/config-4.20.13-200.fc29.x86_64
CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT=1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The
texts.text: The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: power_save
texts.text: power_save

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: setting is applied in
texts.text: setting is applied in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /sound/pci/hda/hda_codec.c
texts.text: /sound/pci/hda/hda_codec.c

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: We can look where
texts.text: We can look where

texts.label: code
texts.orig: codec_set_power_save
texts.text: codec_set_power_save

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is defined in the same file to learn more:
texts.text: is defined in the same file to learn more:

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: This logic looks to see if
texts.text: This logic looks to see if

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CONFIG_PM
texts.text: CONFIG_PM

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is set to know if power management is desired at all. From there, it checks if we disabled power saving but there's a discrete graphics card involved (
texts.text: is set to know if power management is desired at all. From there, it checks if we disabled power saving but there's a discrete graphics card involved (

texts.label: code
texts.orig: codec->auto_runtime_pm
texts.text: codec->auto_runtime_pm

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: ). This check is important because the discrete graphics card cannot power down unless the HDA card suspends at the same time.
texts.text: ). This check is important because the discrete graphics card cannot power down unless the HDA card suspends at the same time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Next, there's a check to see if the delay is greater than 0. This would be the case if
texts.text: Next, there's a check to see if the delay is greater than 0. This would be the case if

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT
texts.text: CONFIG_SND_HDA_POWER_SAVE_DEFAULT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: was set to
texts.text: was set to

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (Fedora's default). If so, the proper auto suspend delays are set.
texts.text: (Fedora's default). If so, the proper auto suspend delays are set.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the delay is 0, then autosuspend is disabled and removed from power management entirely. This is the option I chose and it's working great.
texts.text: If the delay is 0, then autosuspend is disabled and removed from power management entirely. This is the option I chose and it's working great.
